title: Killip Classification for Heart Failure
description: Quantifies heart failure severity in acute coronary syndrome (STEMI or NSTEMI) and predicts 30-day mortality. Based on physical examination findings to stratify risk in myocardial infarction patients.

parameters.name: killip_class
parameters.description: Killip class based on clinical presentation

options.label: Class I - No signs of congestion
options.description: No clinical signs of heart failure

options.label: Class II - S3 and basal rales on auscultation
options.description: Rales in the lungs, third heart sound (S3), and/or elevated jugular venous pressure

options.label: Class III - Acute pulmonary edema
options.description: Overt pulmonary edema with rales throughout lung fields

options.label: Class IV - Cardiogenic shock
options.description: Cardiogenic shock with hypotension (SBP <90 mmHg) and evidence of peripheral vasoconstriction

result.name: killip_result
result.description: Killip classification with mortality risk estimates

ranges.interpretation: Low risk. No clinical signs of heart failure. Standard ACS management appropriate.
Moderate risk. Mild-moderate heart failure. Consider diuretics and close monitoring.
High risk. Severe heart failure with pulmonary edema. Aggressive treatment including diuretics, vasodilators, and consider mechanical support.
Very high risk. Cardiogenic shock requires immediate intervention including inotropes, mechanical circulatory support, and urgent revascularization.

references: Killip T 3rd, Kimball JT. Treatment of myocardial infarction in a coronary care unit. A two year experience with 250 patients. Am J Cardiol. 1967 Oct;20(4):457-64.

Khot UN, Jia G, Moliterno DJ, Lincoff AM, Khot MB, Harrington RA, Topol EJ. Prognostic importance of physical examination for heart failure in non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndromes: the enduring value of Killip classification. JAMA. 2003 Oct 22;290(16):2174-81.

Mello BH, Oliveira GB, Ramos RF, Lopes BB, Barros CB, Carvalho Ede O, et al. Validation of the Killip-Kimball classification and late mortality after acute myocardial infarction. Arq Bras Cardiol. 2014 Aug;103(2):107-17.

DeGeare VS, Boura JA, Grines LL, O'Neill WW, Grines CL. Predictive value of the Killip classification in patients undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention for acute myocardial infarction. Am J Cardiol. 2001 May 1;87(9):1035-8.

notes: Originally developed in 1967 before reperfusion therapy era
Still validated and predictive in modern era with PCI and thrombolytics
Simple bedside assessment requiring only physical examination
Useful for rapid risk stratification in emergency settings
Can guide treatment decisions including reperfusion therapy and mechanical support
Mortality rates have decreased since original study due to modern therapies
Should be used as part of full clinical assessment, not in isolation
Applies to both STEMI and NSTEMI patients
